ALLEGATION:
OFA received a phone call that foster parent 1 hasn't been receiving payments
for foster Child A since child has been in her care. The foster parent has
received two payments for foster child B since October (2018).
INVESTIGATION:
Foster Parent 1 was interviewed. She reported she has been a foster parent for
Homes for Black Children (HFBC) for nine years. She said she never had any
issues with payments until a year ago and payments began to come sporadically or
not at all. She said she complained to her assigned foster care worker who informed
her that she would inform her administration because she had nothing to do with
funding of the agency or payments to foster parents. Foster Parent 1 said she
talked with the president of the agency, and payments continued to move slowly for
foster child B. she said she never had a problem receiving payments for foster Child
A. She said it was after she made the allegation mentioned above things started
moving and she was able to receive payments for foster child B. She said she
received a lump sum payment from the agency. Foster Parent 1 said she did not
want to get the agency into trouble but if she was doing her part of fostering children
in her home, she expected payments to assist in taking care of the children placed in
her home. Foster Parent 1 said she was all caught up with her foster care payments
at this point and that she does not have any additional information to add. She said
if she did not receive her payments on a consistent basis, she would call this
consultant back to discuss her payments.
Foster Child A, age 8, was placed in the home of Foster Parent 1 on 08/27/2017. A
review of the agency payment schedule from the agency accountant show
consistent payments from the agency to foster parent 1. There appeared to be no
problems with the payment for foster child A. Foster Parent 1 admitted that she did
not have any payment issues from the agency in regard to foster child A.
Foster Child B, age 2, was placed in the home of Foster Parent 1 on 09/29/2018. A
review of the agency payment schedule from the agency accountant showed the
following reimbursement to foster parent 1 for foster child B:

A review of payments for foster child B in MiSACWIS indicated that the checks were
sent to the agency timely. It is shown with this schedule that the checks were not
submitted to the foster parent timely.
The director reported that Foster child B was placed with the agency on September
29, 2018 and her first payment was received from the department on February 13,
2019. According to the director, she provided the check amount to the foster parent in
the amount of 1,068.88.
A review of payments for foster child A from the accountant of the agency indicates
that a check went out to the foster parent on a regular basis for foster child A.
The director was interviewed onsite. She acknowledges difficulty with cash flow
stemming from reductions from both foster care and adoption placements for 2017
and 2018. She reported she responded to her service reduction by decreasing its
expenses by downsizing the reduction of staff. She reports the current staffing pattern
allows for a maximum of 33 foster care placement and the agency has 30 active foster
care cases.
The director further reported that the agency failure to receive timely approval for
payments from the department added to her cash flow problems. She reported that
half of her foster care population payments were delayed for more than two months.
She said she takes full responsibility in not following the protocol of getting the
delayed payments taken care of sooner by not following the departments policy and
procedure for payments. She identified the following foster children delayed payment
schedule:

It should be noted that the agency was in non - compliance with special investigation
#2019C0201018 for not following Contract PAFC 50001 – Placing Agency foster care
policy. The report was dated May 24, 2019 whereby the agency submitted a corrective
action plan. The corrective action plan was dated 06/11/2019. The agency is still in the
process of correcting the funding issues with the foster parents.
To date the agency reported they are behind in three foster care payments. The
director reported she will be up to date with all payments by the end of August 2019.
The director identified the three foster parents and the amount of payments owed as
following:
Foster Parent: Type of Placement: Amount Owed:
Foster Parent 2 Licensed Foster Home 1,400.00
Foster Parent 3 Licensed Foster Home 2,200.00
Foster Parent 4 Unlicensed relative 3,400.00
The agency three foster care workers were interviewed onsite regarding foster care
payments.
Foster Care Worker 1 reported she is assigned foster parent 1 case. She reported
foster parent 1 complained to her about her payments not being timely or that she was
not receiving her payments at all from the agency for foster child B. She said she
reported the information to the agency administration. This foster parent made a
complaint on the agency. She said the foster parent told her that due to a complaint
she made on the agency, she has been paid and is up to date on payments for the
foster children in her home.
Foster Care Worker 2 was interviewed onsite. She reported that none of her foster
parents has complained to her regarding payments or not getting paid from the agency.
She offered no other information.
Foster Care worker 3 was interviewed onsite. She reported that none of her assigned
foster parents on her case load has complained to her about not getting paid from the
agency. She offered no other information.
A selection of random foster parents were contacted regarding receiving their foster
parent payments from Homes for Black Children.
Foster parent 2 was interviewed via telephone. She reported she has been a foster
parent for the agency since 2/16/2017. She reported when she became a foster parent
with the agency, she had no issues with payments. She said within the last year the
agency has been slow with payments. She said she does not get her payments
consistently but when the agency give her a check it’s a lump sum. She said the
agency does not stick to a schedule. She said she might get a check on the 15th of the
months and then she might get a check towards the end of the month. Foster Parent 2
5

said she does not complain because she knows she will get paid and that everybody
has money issues from time to time. She said she wish she knew a date of when she
will receive a check. She had no other information to provide.
Foster Parent 3 was interviewed onsite. She has been a foster parent with the agency
since 11/29/2016. She reported the agency owes her money and that she is discussing
the issue with the administration. She was not sure of how much money she is owed.
She said she does not get consistent payments but that she does get a check from time
to time.
Foster Parent 4 was interviewed via telephone. She reported she has been a foster
parent with the agency since 9/23/2015. She said she is adopting her two nephews and
that she was not expecting any money. She said when she received a check from the
agency she was surprised because all she wanted to do was take care of her two
nephews. She said to her knowledge the agency does not owe her any money. She
reported she gets a check regularly. Foster Parent 4 said she does not have any
complaints on the agency at this time. She said her department worker informed her
that she should be getting payments for caring for her nephews and that her worker
made a complaint regarding this issue. She said after the complaint, she was given a
check from the agency and they continue to come on a regular basis. She has no
additional information.
Foster Parent 5 was interviewed via telephone. She has been a foster parent since
12/20/2016. She reported that she does not have any issues with the agency. She said
she gets a check monthly. Her only complaint is that the agency is not consistent with
the payment dates.
APPLICABLE RULE
CONTRACT – Placing Agency Foster Care
PAFC 19-50001
When the contractor’s financial records reveal that
payment for a child has not been provided by MDHHS
within 30 days of receiving all necessary documentation,
the contractor will seek payment resolution by
contacting the direct supervisor of the assigned MDHHS
worker in writing. Any concerns over a payment
authorization or issuance that cannot be resolved within
30 days of the written notice must be reported to the
MDHHS county director for immediate resolution. The
contractor will apprise MDHHS office of child welfare
services and support of any ongoing, unresolved
payment concerns.
6

ANALYSIS: The agency did not utilize the placement agency foster care
contract for the children who the agency had not receive
payments for within 30 days. It is a fact that the agency payment
schedule and payments to foster parents is ineffective and
needs to be revised.
Further the agency has not developed a foster parent payment
schedule despite signing 3600s which states, “The contract
agency must forward the age appropriate rate to the foster
parent in accordance with the contract agency’s foster parent
payment schedule.” Contract language requires the agency to
develop a foster parent payment schedule.
It should be noted that a complaint was initiated on the agency
in March 2019. The report was submitted to the agency on May
2019, complaint #2019C02002018 and the agency submitted a
CAP on 06/11/2019. This complaint came in on 05/08/2019. It
has been 2 months and the agency is still in the process of
correcting this violation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The agency has not obtained an annual audit of all financial accounts as of
May 2019.
APPLICABLE RULE
R400.4108 Financing and audit.
Rule 108. A licensee shall do all of the following:
(a) Obtain an annual audit of all financial accounts. Audits
for nongovernmental institutions shall be conducted
by an independent certified public accountant who is
not administratively related to the agency.
7

ANALYSIS: It should be noted per special investigation
#2019C0201018, the agency was in violation of not
obtaining their independent annual audit of their financial
accounts as of May 2019 for fiscal year 2016 and 2017.
The independent audit has been completed and sent to
the state of Michigan. In a discussion with the executive
director via telephone, she reported that the auditors
reported a (Going concern). The executive director also
reported there was a deficit of $400, 000 for the year of
2016 and a reduction in the deficit to $70, 000 for fiscal
year 2017. The executive director anticipates further
reductions for the fiscal year 2018 and 2019.
It is noted that the State of Michigan has received a copy
of Homes for Black Children internal audit for years 16
and 17.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon an acceptable corrective action plan and time to correct this violation, I
recommend Homes for Black Children continue with their regular license.
